title: Illuminated Orbital Shaker for Microalgae Culture

source.description:
The components for the algal shaker can be sourced from four types of suppliers.
  • Laboratory equipment supplier
  • Electronics parts distributor
  • Printed circuit board manufacturer
  • 3D printing service (or in-house 3D printer)
The orbital shaker can be sourced from laboratory equipment suppliers. The orbital shaker described in this protocol was bought on
ebay
.
All electronics components and mechanical fixings can be bought from electronics parts distributors. In the described case, it was
Farnell
. The clear acrylic sheet can be bought from specialist local supplier of sheet plastic or can be ordered laser cut to size and shape local laser-cut service providers.
The
custom-made printed circuit board
(PCB) simplifies and speeds up the assembly and results in a smaller, more robust circuit. Here,
Seeed Technology
was used for their low-cost, high-quality PCBs production service.
The electronics is housed in a custom case. It can be produced on a fused-deposition modelling 3D printer - in-house or outsourced to third-party manufacturers. An in-house
Stratasys Uprint SE Plus
was used here.

source.title: Procuring Parts for Algal Shaker

{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"30tsm","text":"LED Illuminator Parts","type":"header-three"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bl72l","text":"","type":"header-three"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":28,"offset":438}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"85qj5","text":"The LED illuminator consists of LED strips attached to a heatsink, cooling fans and wires that connect all components together and the LED controller electronics circuit. The list also includes a wall socket plug-in power supply and a 24-hour time switch to control the daily sequence of the LED illuminator. The components required to build the LED illuminator are listed in the table below and in the "LED Illuminator Parts" tab of the OrbitalShaker_PartsList.xlsx spreadsheet:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"98jle","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dmn6s","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"95q1j","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"94ru3","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":23,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"5p8o","text":"Note for Non-UK Regions","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3cccu","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bk86v","text":"The power supply and the 24-hour timer (items 3 & 9) are for UK sockets. Other parts of the world have different line Voltage and sockets. Find a 30V/1A power supply with a 2.1mm DC connector and a programmable 24-hour socket timer that are suitable and certified for use in your region.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aa87l","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":27,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"59dll","text":"Note for Non-Metric Regions","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"82l5q","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":283,"offset":0,"style":"italic"},{"length":1,"offset":34,"style":"sup"}],"key":"4ah16","text":"Items 6 & 7 are cables with 0.5 mm2 cross-section. This is roughly equivalent to AWG 21 cables. Choose a suitable cable, which is close to this gauge. Thicker cables can force the LED strips to lift off from the heatsink and thinner gauges may be insufficient to support the current.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4pf5l","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":31,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9r5k9","text":"Note on the Clear Acrylic Sheet","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"abktc","text":"Here, an off-the-shelf clear acrylic was used. The 4 mm (5/32") thick clear acrylic is ideal. A thinner one might be to weak and a thicker one might be impossible to fix to the stand-offs. However the exact make and size of the sheet are irrelevant. Polycarbonate could also be used instead of acrylic. It may be easier to drill and cheaper, but absorb more The orbital shaker described in this protocol was bought on ebay.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fqcq7","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":7,"offset":131}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4phvr","text":"All electronics components and mechanical fixings can be bought from electronics parts distributors. In the described case, it was Farnell.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6bmer","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7cehu","text":"The clear acrylic sheet can be bought from specialist local supplier of sheet plastic or can be ordered laser cut to size and shape by local laser-cut service providers.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"430r2","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"length":1,"offset":4},{"key":3,"length":25,"offset":5},{"key":4,"length":1,"offset":30},{"key":5,"length":16,"offset":136}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ferho","text":"The custom-made printed circuit board  (PCB) simplifies and speeds up the assembly and results in a smaller, more robust circuit. Here, Seeed Technology was used for their low-cost, high-quality PCBs production service.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4kln","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"length":24,"offset":173}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3541d","text":"The electronics is housed in a custom case. It can be produced on a fused-deposition modelling 3D printer - in-house or outsourced to third-party manufacturers. An in-house Stratasys Uprint SE Plus was used here.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/www.ebay.co.uk","guid":"DB7C6937B40340D9A7DCBFFD286271EB"}},{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/www.farnell.com","guid":"C903D025ABB64075A3EA5FDE0AAB1485"}},{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/github.com\/jnedbal\/LEDregulator.git","guid":"3E328A55F51B46FF804584B08BB53A70"}},{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/github.com\/jnedbal\/LEDregulator.git","guid":"89E9D7175558417ABF0B9C13C40F216D"}},{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/github.com\/jnedbal\/LEDregulator.git","guid":"B8FBE59AB8524E52875FC8D899F1C5E2"}},{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/www.seeedstudio.com","guid":"1EFB987AE72647FE82732867F3AA232B"}},{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/www.stratasys.com\/-\/media\/files\/printer-spec-sheets\/pss_fdm_uprintseplus_0117a.pdf","guid":"0DBB5F7886294EEDA815ED13BEC9D4D7"}}]}

The LED controller electronics regulates the LED current, adjusting the irradiance of the sample according the experimental needs. It also powers the fans cooling down the LEDs. The electronic circuit assembly requires surface-mount component soldering equipment and skills. The smallest parts used are in 0603 package. This size allows soldering with a decent soldering station, flux, watch-makers tweezers, an a bit of experience. The soldering should take no more than 1-2 hours. It is followed by testing the circuit and finally cleaning any excess flux.
Consider the safety of the soldering process and observe local regulations. Soldering creates risks of fire, exposure to hazardous fumes, and skin exposure to the soldering flux. Take all necessary precautions. Keep the work area tidy, especially devoid of any combustible materials. Never leave the soldering iron unattended while hot. Use fume extractor during soldering and laboratory gloves when handling the flux-stained PCB.

{"blocks":[{"key":"4us6v","text":"Adding the Power Supply Connection","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":34,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6amdg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fimag","text":"In this step, the power supply connection is added and the first test of the circuit is performed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6lk13","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"553l8","text":"Solder the power supply connector (J1), toggle switch (SW1), the fuse holder (F1), and insert T1.25A fuse into the fuse holder according to the image below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7sune","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ehq51","text":"  ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"11v4p","text":"\u200bWith the components soldered in place, connect the +30V power supply to DC power jack (J1). Make sure the T1.25A fuse is in the fuse holder (F1). Use a digital multimeter in the DC Voltage mode to probe the Voltages on test points of the board.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8ppo4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6id2t","text":"Make sure the toggle switch (SW1) is in the position as shown in the image above. Connect the multimeter ground lead (black) to the test point labelled GND1 in the image above. Connect the positive lead (red) to the test point labelled +1.25V in the image above. The multimeter should show a value close to 1.25\u00a0V on the display. If it does not, check the soldering. On an occasion, we found the shunt reference D1 (MAX6006) failed after assembly and had to replace it. It may be that this component is quite sensitive to mishandling and so you may need to replace it if it does not work before proceeding to the next steps.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":152,"style":"bold"},{"length":6,"offset":236,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dsaoj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3m98u","text":"Switch the toggle switch (SW1) to the opposite position to the one shown in the image above. With the multimeter ground lead connected to the GND2 test point, probe the Voltage at the testpoint labelled +30V. Make sure the measured Voltage is close to +30\u00a0V. If not, check the soldering. The only component that may be susceptible to failing due to mishandling is Q1. Check if it works and replace it if required.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":142,"style":"bold"},{"length":4,"offset":203,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9ebgh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8s6m","text":"Do not proceed to the next steps, until you verified the circuit works as described above. Replacing components will become hard or impossible once the remaining large through-hole components are soldered to the PCB.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":216,"offset":0,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"image","data":{"guid":"2A9851C04CF711EA81CEC50EDAD5F90B","height":628.509090909091,"id":55690,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"99tgm","text":"The DC power supply connector, fuse in a fuseholder, and toggle switch are soldered next. The partial circuit functionality is tested by connecting the power supply to the DC power supply connector and ensuring the expected voltages are measured at the test points highlighted by the black and red arrows in the diagram.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image\/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"phpnLOVE5.png","placeholder":"https:\/\/s3.amazonaws.com\/protocols-files\/public\/2adc685aba2669f84eefd3e3bf54fe2597586d9c2ca8f5ecb2b8de1c2076d7d7\/bynk2kzw.png","shadow":false,"source":"https:\/\/s3.amazonaws.com\/protocols-files\/public\/2adc685aba2669f84eefd3e3bf54fe2597586d9c2ca8f5ecb2b8de1c2076d7d7\/bynk2kzw.png","width":580}}]}

Solder a DIP-8 socket into the place for the rotary switch SW2, according to the image below (do not solder the rotary switch directly into the PCB):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":12,"offset":43,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":53,"offset":225,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":3,"offset":126,"style":"bold"},{"length":6,"offset":225,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2lc3k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4r4eh","text":"  ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"3ppfh","text":"Now, insert the rotary switch into the DIP-8 socket that has just been soldered to the PCB, according to the figure below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"mile","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4d7gd","text":"  ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"ak82p","text":"With the switch in place and the +30V power supply connected to DC jack (J1), use a multimeter to test the Voltage between test points labelled GND and VAR. The Voltage measured should vary in steps of 1.25\u00a0V, 1.09\u00a0V, 0.93\u00a0V, 0.78\u00a0V, 0.62\u00a0V, 0.46\u00a0V, and 0.30\u00a0V, which are respective to rotary switch positions of \u2022, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. Check these Voltages for every rotary switch position. If any vary significantly, check the soldering and measure the resistances of the SMD resistors. These include the screw terminal connectors and the adjustable LED driver.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image\/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"phpTszP8F.png","placeholder":"https:\/\/s3.amazonaws.com\/protocols-files\/public\/2adc685aba2669f84eefd3e3bf54fe2597586d9c2ca8f5ecb2b8de1c2076d7d7\/bynp2kzw.png","shadow":false,"source":"https:\/\/s3.amazonaws.com\/protocols-files\/public\/2adc685aba2669f84eefd3e3bf54fe2597586d9c2ca8f5ecb2b8de1c2076d7d7\/bynp2kzw.png","width":580}}]}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8ir32","text":"Cleaning the PCB","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"frjmm","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"au79j","text":"Cleaning the PCB from residual flux is important to avoid long-term corrosion and possible future reliability issues. There are professional PCB cleaners in spray, which dissolve the flux that can be wiped off together with the solvent.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bbrle","text":"Instead, I use a widely available solvent isopropanol (isopropyl alcohol, IPA, propan-2-ol) for cleaning. Get a small tub just about fitting the PCB with a lid (an old margarine tub works fine).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":11,"offset":42,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8fq9f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9ul11","text":"Place the PCB into the tub and cover it completely with the solvent (the parts do not need to be completely submerged).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3gl6i","text":"Close the lid and let it soak for at least 10 minutes (or even overnight). This should soften the flux.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4og3f","text":"Use a toothbrush and a toothpick to rub and scrape off any flux deposits from the PCB.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7p8u7","text":"Empty the tub with the solvent according to local waste disposal regulations.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6vdsb","text":"Place the PCB back into the tub, cover it with fresh isopropanol, close the tub lid and let the board soak for additional 10 minutes.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"29q9s","text":"Brush and pick any residual flux.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"949fu","text":"Flick any residual solvent from the board and let it dry.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3s089","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"54nc2","text":"The above steps explained how to clean the flux from the printed circuit board for long-term reliability of the LED regulator circuit.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7inf5","text":"Summary","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7idsv","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4bos7","text":"This document described the assembly process for the LED controller electronic circuit. The assembly took place in steps, each followed by test instructions to verify the function of the circuit before embarking on the next assembly steps. By the end, the circuit board is ready to be installed into a custom case, which is described in the 3D printing case for LED controller document.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"17d4r","text":"The LED controller electronics regulates the LED current, adjusting the irradiance of the sample according the experimental needs. It also powers the fans cooling down the LEDs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8ncor","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"86juu","text":"This document is part of the Illuminated Orbital Shaker for Microalgae Culture project:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":87,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3p7qm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9riad","text":"\u200bProcuring Parts for Algal Shaker\u200b","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"48lqa","text":"\u200bAssembling LED Controller Electronics (this document)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":15,"offset":39,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a2hte","text":"\u200b3D Printing Case for LED Controller\u200b","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5f3ij","text":"\u200bAssembling Cooled LED Illuminator\u200b","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"do9jv","text":"\u200bCutting and Drilling Clear Acrylic Sheet\u200b","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fg307","text":"\u200bAssembling Algal Shaker","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

The electronics circuit is housed inside a case, which protects the circuit from damage and the users from exposure to live voltage. The
case for the LED controller
can be 3D printed in-house or outsourced to a specialist supplier. I used
Stratasys Uprint SE Plus
, a fused-deposition modeling printer. The finishing is rough, but serves the purpose. A laser-sintering printer would produce a more detailed and premium finish.

source.title: 3D Printing Case for LED Controller

steps.data: {"blocks":[{"key":"818jd","text":"Obtain Source Files","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4a2tp","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cv8o3","text":"The electronics circuit has been designed in KiCAD. KiCAD PCB files can be opened in FreeCAD. This in turn allows exporting the 3D render of the PCB into an industry-standard STEP file format. The STEP file can then be imported into Onshape, which is a 3D CAD tool. Onshape was then used to create a 3D model of a case to hold the electronics printed circuit boards with all its components. The case consists of two parts, the Top and the Bottom, which are fixed together by screws during the final assembly. The model of the case with the embedded electronics circuit is openly available on the LED regulator case project page.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":5,"offset":45},{"key":1,"length":7,"offset":85},{"key":2,"length":7,"offset":233},{"key":3,"length":7,"offset":266},{"key":4,"length":18,"offset":596}],"data":[]},{"key":"516du","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bhtr5","text":"  ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"evusp","text":"3D printing, whether done in-house or outsourced, requires STL files to work from. The STL files can be found on the LED regulator case project page in a subfolder named STL Files, as shown in the screenshot below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":170,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"length":18,"offset":117}],"data":[]},{"key":"ufv3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"gpc0","text":"  There are two files in this folder, named LEDregulator\u00a0-\u00a0Box Top.stl and LEDregulator\u00a0-\u00a0BoxBottom.stl. {"blocks":[{"key":"e913l","text":"3D Printing","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cmaeb","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ec9eq","text":"There is no general instruction on how to run a 3D printer. We used an in-house Stratasys uPrint SE Plus fused deposition modelling printer with printed support according to manufacturers instructions. The support material was subsequently dissolved by immersing the 3D printed parts in a warm hydrogen peroxide bath.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":24,"offset":80}],"data":[]},{"key":"61g19","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"kd0r","text":"This step is potentially hazardous. All local regulations and procedures were observed and personal protection equipment was used.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":130,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"br28b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2kap2","text":"Finally, the two parts were thoroughly washed with copious amounts of water and dried prior to further processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","data":{"url":"https:\/\/www.stratasys.com\/-\/media\/files\/printer-spec-sheets\/pss_fdm_uprintseplus_0117a.pdf","guid":"171CDFE3F1FF4F86BB1E8E64F6773196"}}]}

{"blocks":[{"key":"84kb0","text":"Tapping Threaded Holes in the 3D Printed Case","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dh12n","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"lqvd","text":"The Top part of the case is printed with four blind holes in each corner, highlighted by the black arrows in the image below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4jkrr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5q055","text":"  ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"5j78o","text":"\u200b","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5g4fh","text":"Use an M3 thread tap to create M3 threaded holes in each corner. In areas, where Imperial thread sizes are in use, swap the M3 threads for locally common #4-40 UNC threads instead. They have similar diameter and due to their courser thread spacing, they are better suited for soft materials like plastic.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3rag3","text":"The thread is typically created in three steps using three thread taps with progressively deeper cutting threads. Start with the shallowest thread tap and finish with the deepest thread tap. Some tap manufacturers help identifying the order of taps by the number of engraved lines (see image below). First comes a tap with one line, followed by a tap with two lines, and finished with a tap with no lines. Use a tap wrench to do the thread tapping. An illustrative image of an M3 thread tap set and a tap wrench are in the image below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"46ohu","text":"\u200b","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5hecd","text":" Where imperial threads are common, four #4-40\u00a0UNC\u00a03\/8\"-long countersunk screws should be used instead. The assembly is really trivial and only takes a screwdriver or an Allen key, depending on which screw head type is available. source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"bt7v4","text":"The electronics control circuit for the illuminated orbital shaker should be housed in a case to protect it from damage by short-circuit, but also to minimize injury by electrical current and fire hazard.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3v7uj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"smoj","text":"This document is part of the Illuminated Orbital Shaker for Microalgae Culture project:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":87,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ats8u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1tuc","text":"\u200bProcuring Parts for Algal Shaker\u200b","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2c1m9","text":"Assembling LED Controller Electronics","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f1rl5","text":"\u200b3D Printing Case for LED Controller (this document)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":15,"offset":37,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fpcts","text":"\u200bAssembling Cooled LED Illuminator\u200b","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3204i","text":"\u200bCutting and Drilling Clear Acrylic Sheet\u200b","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"69dqu","text":"\u200bAssembling Algal Shaker","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c9ev8","text":"\u200b","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

The LED illuminator is built from LED strips mounted on top of a heatsink. The heat sink is passively cooled when the LEDs are operated at low current. It is actively cooled by small fans at higher current to avoid overheating the algal cultures. The assembly of the cooled LED illuminator consists of glueing the LED strips to the underside of the heat sink and soldering them in a daisy-chain fashion for connection to the LED controller. The fans are also glued to the heatsink and connected to the LED controller.

source.title: Assembling Cooled LED Illuminator

{"blocks":[{"key":"3ftab","text":"Fixing LED Controller to the Heatsink","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"81lqf","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7o3dc","text":"The LED controller can be left lying next to the heatsink on the shaking incubator. The fixing does not need to be done at this point and could be postponed until everything is tested and working. The primary reason to fix the LED controller to the heatsink is to keep the wiring tidy and reliable in the long-term by minimizing risk of snapping of the cables.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3hq4p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"doljj","text":"Position the heatsink on the edge of a table to have it standing sideways. Make sure the LED controller can be mounted sideways, as in the image below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eccvh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"edog0","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"ejkra","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dc1lm","text":"Apply the general purpose glue to the side of the heatsink, where the LED controller is to be mounted. Press the LED controller into the glue and make sure that the bottom of the heatsink and the bottom of the LED controller are spaced at least 6 mm (1\/4\") apart. This is to ensure that the LED controller stays above the rim of the orbital shaker platform. The rim is about 6 mm high. If you have a different orbital shaker, make sure that either the heatsink with the LED controller fit entirely onto the platform, or check for minimum clearance required to accommodate the platform rim. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eiu5u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dkkl0","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"eqf7b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9p34q","text":"Let the glue dry for 10-30 minutes, depending on the type of the glue and environmental conditions. Even once the glue is partially set, handle the unit with care, as the glue will initially be quite weak. Once happy with the strength of the glue, lay the heatsink back on its back:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"160o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a43qm","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"54jno","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ohcl","text":"Solder short lengths of red and black 0.5 mm2 cables to an unconnected end of the LED strip. {"blocks":[{"key":"2npjf","text":"Testing the LED controller","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fqnls","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8d6ri","text":"Connect the 30V\/1A Power Supply to the LED controller and plug it into the socket. Use a screwdriver to adjust the LED brightness by turning the rotary switch between the end positions (\u2022), for maximum brightness, and (6), for minimum brightness.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1a6ut","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bkmmp","text":"LEDs are in the trickle mode and fans stationary:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3ukif","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6u30","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"2ace6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8mis","text":"LEDs are in the controlled current mode and the fans are spinning:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4lbb1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7bitu","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"8gglh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ab6u6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"image","data":{"guid":"76F5CFC053D211EAA295677ABD663F52","height":224,"id":56236,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"afk01","text":"LEDs glow is dim in the trickle current mode. A
clear acrylic sheet
is mounted over the LEDs and serves as the platform on which the algal cultures are placed for shaking. The acrylic can be cut out and drilled using a hack saw and a drill in a workshop. Alternatively, it can be cut using a laser cutter in-house or externally.

source.title: Cutting and Drilling Clear Acrylic Sheet

source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"bl1i","text":"A clear acrylic sheet is cut to to form a transparent platform, on which the algal cell cultures in flasks are being shaken.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dl3sb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"amofg","text":"This document is part of the Illuminated Orbital Shaker for Microalgae Culture project:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":87,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2s2fg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5e10n","text":"Procuring Parts for Algal Shaker","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"agk19","text":"Assembling LED Controller Electronics","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3idm6","text":"3D Printing Case for LED Controller","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ai66r","text":"Assembling Cooled LED Illuminator (this document)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7r8je","text":"Cutting and Drilling Clear Acrylic Sheet","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dltlg","text":"Assembling Algal Shaker","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Assembling the Algal Orbital Shaker is the last an most rewarding step. The acrylic sheet is mounted on top of the orbital shaker on metal stand-offs. The cooled LED illuminator is laid underneath the acrylic. The antislip silicon mat supplied with the orbital shaker is placed on top of the acrylic. The LED controller is connected to a socket through a 24-hour timer with the day/night cycle programmed. Once powered, the algal shaker should be working.

source.title: Assembling Algal Shaker

description:
Microalgae are grown for the research on photosynthesis, biotechnology, and water-environment ecology. Specialized laboratories typically use calibrated commercial equipment, which agitates the microalgae culture by shaking or bubbling, controls the irradiance, temperature, and CO2 content. Such commercial incubators may be out of reach for some laboratories, like those not specializing in microalgae research, teaching laboratories, or laboratories in low resource settings. Our research uses microalgae cultures during the development and validation of advanced microscopy techniques. We lacked access to and the budget for a commercial incubator. We solved the problem by building a stand-alone orbital shaking incubator with an in-built variable light source and a 24-hour timer. The shaker features a homogeneously illuminated growth area of 20 cm × 15 cm, which is suitable for three T75 tissue culture flasks or four 100 ml Erlenmeyer flasks. The overall material cost was around £300 and assembly time of about two days. We tested the shaker with fresh-water microalgae Desmodesmus quadricauda and Chlorella vulgaris. Both microalgae cultures have been grown continuously for seven months in the incubator. We studied their growth under different light conditions to validate the function of the shaker. The protocol outlines the step-by-step process to the building of this microalgae shaker.
Here, we describe an illuminated orbital shaker designed for culture of microalgae suspensions. It was optimized for production cost, simplicity, low power consumption, design flexibility, and consistent and controllable growth light intensity. The instrument agitates and illuminates microalgae suspensions grown inside flasks. The agitation speed is variable while the light intensity is both variable and programmable (24-hour light/dark diurnal cycle).
The instrument offers a vastly cheaper alternative to commercial instruments for many laboratory applications, making it especially well suited for teaching and poorly-resourced research laboratories. It improves on home-built microalgae growth systems by offering consistent and well characterized illumination light intensity, low power consumption and heat dissipation. The illuminated growth area is 20 cm × 15 cm, which is suitable for three T75 tissue culture flasks or six 100 ml Erlenmeyer flasks. The photosynthetic photon flux density, measured inside an Erlenmeyer flask, is variable in eight steps (26−800 μmol·m−2·s−1). The overall material cost is around £300 (including an entry-level orbital shaker). The build takes about two days, requiring electronics assembly and machine workshop skills. The instrument build is documented in a set of protocols, design files, and source code. Its design can be readily modified, scaled, and adapted for other orbital shakers and specific experimental requirements.
The illuminated orbital shaker is ideal for growing small volumes of microalgae for research and teaching. It can readily replace commercial systems in many common microalgae culture application for a fraction of their cost. It outperforms typical home-made systems by offering consistent and predictable illumination light intensity and low power consumption.
